summary: This FBI 302 form documents an interview with former US Virgin Islands Attorney General Denise George on October 2, 2023. She details political pressure from Governor Albert Bryan regarding a travel waiver for Jeffrey Epstein, her subsequent investigation into Epstein's estate for fraud and human trafficking, and her eventual termination after filing a lawsuit against JPMorgan. The document reveals connections between Epstein, Virgin Islands officials, and legal representatives.

persons.name: Denise George
persons.role: Former United States Virgin Islands Attorney General
persons.context: The interviewee who filed a complaint and provided a statement about political pressure related to Jeffrey Epstein's waiver request, her investigation into his estate, and her eventual termination.

persons.name: Albert Bryan
persons.context: The Governor who pressured George to grant a travel waiver for Jeffrey Epstein and later pressured her to settle and end the investigation into Epstein's estate.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the investigation; requested a travel waiver, moved assets to the USVI, and whose estate was sued for fraud and human trafficking.

persons.name: Erika Kellerhals
persons.context: Epstein's lawyer who submitted the waiver request to the Attorney General and filed a probate petition after his death. Employees were instructed to alert her if questioned.

persons.name: Vincent Franklin Frazer
persons.role: Previous US Virgin Islands Attorney General
persons.context: A former AG who initially granted, then later rescinded, a travel waiver for Jeffrey Epstein. George believed he was pressured by then-Governor John De Jongh.

persons.name: Carol Thomas-Jacobs
persons.context: The acting AG who rescinded Epstein's travel waiver after he was detained in the Dominican Republic.

persons.name: John De Jongh
persons.role: Former Governor of the Virgin Islands
persons.context: The former Governor who, according to George, pressured AG Frazer to grant Epstein the travel waiver.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.context: Identified as a participant in Epstein's human trafficking operation and later added as a co-conspirator in the civil case.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Identified as a participant who coordinated fraudulent marriages for immigration status as part of Epstein's trafficking operation. Added as a co-conspirator.

persons.name: Carolyn P. Hermon-Percell
persons.context: The judge before whom Kellerhals filed a probate petition for Epstein's estate. Appointed by Governor Bryan.

persons.name: Anderson Poleon
persons.role: Governor's Chief of Security / Former VIPD officer
persons.context: Bryan's Chief of Security, a former officer who sued the VI government. Bryan frequently asked for updates on his case and called George with him on speakerphone.

persons.name: Jason Charles
persons.role: Part of Generation Now / Southland Gaming liaison
persons.context: Member of 'Generation Now' and SOUTHLAND GAMING's liaison to the VI government. Good friends with Jenifer O'neal.

persons.name: John Engerman
persons.context: Member of 'Generation Now' and Albert Bryan's campaign manager.

persons.name: David Bornn
persons.role: Chief of Legal for Bryan / former Kellerhals employee
persons.context: Member of 'Generation Now', former employee of Erika Kellerhals, and current Chief of Legal for Governor Bryan. Contacted George on behalf of Kellerhals.

persons.name: Jenifer O'neal
persons.context: Good friend of Jason Charles (SOUTHLAND GAMING liaison) and called the governor to complain about the AG's actions against Southland Gaming.

persons.name: Henry Smock
persons.context: The individual Governor Bryan instructed George to select as the mediator for the Epstein estate settlement.

persons.name: Carlton Dowe
persons.context: Sent by Governor Bryan to convince George to settle the Epstein estate case. Indicated he does things for Bryan but has a line he won't cross.

persons.name: Linda Singer
persons.role: Point of contact for Motley Rice
persons.context: The point of contact at the law firm Motley Rice, which assisted the USVI with the investigation into Epstein's estate.

persons.name: Christopher J. Sebero
persons.context: The FBI agent who conducted the interview with Denise George and drafted the 302 report.

connections.description: Governor Bryan repeatedly pressured Attorney General George regarding the Epstein waiver and investigation, ultimately leading to her termination.
Bryan urged the AG to grant a travel waiver for Epstein and later sought to limit the investigation into Epstein's estate.
Kellerhals was Epstein's legal representative, handling his waiver request, estate planning, and probate.
Kahn was identified as a participant in Epstein's human trafficking operation.
Indyke was identified as a participant who coordinated fraudulent marriages as part of Epstein's trafficking operation.
Bornn is the Chief of Legal for Governor Bryan and a former employee of Epstein's lawyer, Erika Kellerhals.
Bornn is a former employee of Kellerhals, and contacted the AG on Kellerhals's behalf during the Epstein investigation.
George believed former Governor De Jongh pressured then-AG Frazer to grant Epstein the travel waiver.
Poleon is Bryan's Chief of Security. Bryan showed unusual interest in Poleon's unrelated lawsuit against the government.
Dowe acted as an intermediary for Bryan, attempting to convince AG George to settle the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein Travel Waiver Request
events.description: Shortly after taking office, AG Denise George was informed by Governor Albert Bryan that Jeffrey Epstein wanted a waiver from a 21-day reporting requirement. His lawyer, Erika Kellerhals, submitted a formal request. George denied the waiver.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested in New York on a Saturday. A meeting between his lawyer Kellerhals and AG George, scheduled for the following Wednesday, never occurred due to his arrest. Epstein later died in custody.

events.title: CICO Lawsuit Filed Against Epstein Estate
events.description: AG George, with the law firm Motley Rice, filed a Civil Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO) lawsuit against the Epstein estate, alleging fraud and that assets were proceeds of criminal activity.

events.title: Lawsuit Filed Against JPMorgan
events.description: AG Denise George filed a legal action against JPMorgan related to the Epstein case.

events.title: Termination of AG Denise George
events.description: Denise George was informed she was terminated as Attorney General. A stated reason was that no AG should file actions without notifying the Governor.

events.title: Settlement with Epstein Estate
events.description: The Epstein estate and the US Virgin Islands settled the civil lawsuit for $105 million. The estate denied all wrongdoing.

locations: St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, United States
keyFacts: Former USVI AG Denise George alleges Governor Albert Bryan pressured her to grant a travel waiver for Jeffrey Epstein and later to settle the investigation into his estate.
The investigation into Epstein's USVI estate uncovered alleged human trafficking operations involving associates Richard Kahn and Darren Indyke, who coordinated fraudulent marriages for victims.
George was terminated as AG shortly after filing a lawsuit against JPMorgan in December 2022, with a cited reason being her failure to notify the Governor before filing.
Epstein's legal representative, Erika Kellerhals, instructed all Epstein employees with NDAs to say nothing to law enforcement and to alert her if questioned.
The USVI's civil case against the Epstein estate resulted in a $105 million settlement, though the estate denied all wrongdoing.
